1→# Project Context
     2→
     3→## Purpose
     4→Crossworld is a prototyping platform for a Nostr-based metaverse. It provides a web-based 3D voxel world with decentralized identity, voice chat, and real-time physics. The project combines Rust (compiled to WebAssembly) for high-performance core systems with TypeScript/React for the user interface.
     5→
     6→## Tech Stack
     7→
     8→### Backend (Rust → WebAssembly)
     9→- **Rust Edition**: 2021 (cube/physics), 2024 (world)
    10→- **WASM Compilation**: wasm-pack with web target
    11→- **Physics Engine**: Rapier3D (git version for latest features)
    12→- **Voxel System**: Custom octree-based cube engine with CSM format support
    13→- **Math Library**: glam 0.29 with serde support
    14→- **Serialization**: serde with wasm-bindgen integration
    15→- **Logging**: tracing + tracing-wasm
    16→
    17→### Frontend (TypeScript/React)
    18→- **Runtime**: Bun (for all build tasks per global conventions)
    19→- **Framework**: React 18 with TypeScript 5.8
    20→- **Build Tool**: Vite 6
    21→- **UI Framework**: Chakra UI 2.10.9 with Emotion
    22→- **3D Rendering**: Three.js 0.170
    23→- **Routing**: React Router DOM 7.1.3
    24→- **Nostr SDK**: Applesauce 4.0 (accounts, core, react, relay, signers)
    25→- **Voice/Streaming**: MoQ (Media over QUIC) - @kixelated packages
    26→- **Utilities**: nostr-tools 2.16.2, react-icons, react-markdown
    27→
    28→### Infrastructure
    29→- **Task Runner**: just (justfile for common tasks)
    30→- **Package Manager**: Bun (workspace-based monorepo)
    31→- **Version Control**: Git (currently on 'planet' branch, main branch for PRs)
    32→
    33→## Project Conventions
    34→
    35→### Code Style
    36→
    37→#### File Naming
    38→- **React Components**: PascalCase.tsx (e.g., SelectAvatar.tsx)
    39→- **Utilities/Services**: kebab-case.ts (e.g., avatar-state.ts)
    40→- **Types**: Co-located with implementation or in dedicated types/ directory
    41→
    42→#### Import Organization
    43→Groups in order:
    44→1. External dependencies (React, Three.js, etc.)
    45→2. Internal absolute imports (from src/)
    46→3. Relative imports (from ./ or ../)
    47→
    48→#### Numeric Values with Units
    49→Always include units in variable names for clarity:
    50→```typescript
    51→const timeout_ms = 5000;
    52→const distance_m = 10.5;
    53→const angle_rad = Math.PI / 4;
    54→```
    55→
    56→#### Logging
    57→- Use console logging with prefixes for easy filtering (e.g., `[AvatarState]`)
    58→- Include relevant context in error messages
    59→
    60→### Architecture Patterns
    61→
    62→#### Data Validation Philosophy: Reset over Migration
    63→- **Early Development Stage**: Data formats change frequently
    64→- **No Legacy Mappings**: Don't maintain mappings of old identifiers to new ones
    65→- **Fail Fast**: If data doesn't match expected format, reset to initial state
    66→- **Simple Validation**: Check current valid formats only
    67→- **User Impact**: Acceptable to reset user selections during active development
    68→
    69→#### State Management
    70→- **Local Component State**: useState for UI-only state
    71→- **Props**: For parent-child communication
    72→- **Services**: For shared business logic and state
    73→- **Avoid Global State**: Unless absolutely necessary
    74→
    75→#### Coordinate System
    76→- **Unified Centered System**: All components use the same world space coordinate system
    77→- **Phased Initialization**: Parallel loading with dependency management
    78→
    79→#### Component Architecture
    80→- Pure functions where possible (easier to test)
    81→- Dependency injection for testability
    82→- Atomic and predictable state updates
    83→- Avoid deep object mutations; prefer creating new objects
    84→
    85→### Testing Strategy
    86→
    87→#### Rust Crates
    88→- **Comprehensive Test Suite**: 33 raycast tests in cube crate (all passing)
    89→- **Run Tests**: `cargo test --workspace` or `just test`
    90→
    91→#### TypeScript/React
    92→- **Type Checking**: Strict TypeScript compilation
    93→- **Build Validation**: `bun run build` (includes type checking)
    94→- **Manual Testing**: Test features through UI during development
    95→
    96→#### Pre-Deployment Checks
    97→Use `just check` which runs:
    98→- `cargo check --workspace`
    99→- `cargo clippy --workspace -- -D warnings`
   100→- `cargo fmt --check`
   101→- WASM build
   102→- TypeScript build
   103→
   104→### Git Workflow
   105→
   106→#### Branch Strategy
   107→- **Main Branch**: `main` (use for PRs)
   108→- **Current Branch**: `planet`
   109→- **Repository Status**: Clean working directory
   110→
   111→#### Recent Work
   112→- Avatar persistence and initialization improvements
   113→- Removal of excessive logging
   114→- WebGL 3D texture error fixes
   115→- World panel settings centralization
   116→- Avatar selector UI improvements
   117→
   118→## Domain Context
   119→
   120→### Nostr Integration
   121→- **Identity System**: Nostr public keys (npub/hex) as player IDs
   122→- **Discovery**: Nostr events for server/player discovery
   123→- **Chat**: Decentralized chat using Nostr events
   124→- **Live Events**: NIP-33 replaceable events for world configuration
   125→- **Tool**: worldtool CLI for managing Nostr live events
   126→
   127→### Voxel System (Cube Crate)
   128→- **Octree Structure**: Hierarchical voxel storage with configurable depths
   129→- **Raycasting**: High-performance ray-cube intersection
   130→- **Mesh Generation**: Optimized geometry for rendering
   131→- **CSM Format**: Custom Cube Script Model format for voxel data
   132→- **Palette Support**: Color palette system for models
   133→
   134→### Physics System
   135→- **Engine**: Rapier3D physics simulation
   136→- **Voxel Collision**: Custom collision detection for voxel geometry
   137→- **Character Controller**: Avatar movement and collision
   138→- **Real-time Simulation**: Integrated with rendering loop
   139→
   140→### Voice Chat (MoQ)
   141→- **Protocol**: Media over QUIC (MoQ) for spatial audio
   142→- **Relay Server**: Local or public MoQ relay
   143→- **WebTransport**: Browser-native WebTransport API
   144→- **Location Tracking**: Spatial audio based on avatar positions
   145→- **Setup Tool**: worldtool CLI can manage MoQ relay server
   146→
   147→### Rendering Pipeline
   148→- **Three.js Integration**: 3D scene management
   149→- **Dual Rendering**: GPU (Three.js) + CPU (custom raytracer)
   150→- **Shaders**: Custom shader system for voxel rendering
   151→- **Post-Processing**: Effects pipeline
   152→
   153→## Important Constraints
   154→
   155→### Technical
   156→- **WASM Target**: Must compile to wasm32-unknown-unknown
   157→- **WebTransport Requirement**: TLS certificates required (mkcert for dev)
   158→- **Browser Compatibility**: Modern browsers with WebTransport support
   159→- **Build Time**: WASM compilation can take 2-3 minutes in release mode
   160→- **Getrandom**: Required for WASM builds (transitive dependency)
   161→
   162→### Development
   163→- **Bun Required**: All npm operations must use bun (per global conventions)
   164→- **Just Tool**: Task automation uses justfile
   165→- **OpenSpec System**: Use for change proposals and architectural decisions
   166→- **No Documentation Proactivity**: Don't create markdown docs unless requested
   167→
   168→### Performance
   169→- **Release Optimization**: opt-level = 3, lto = true
   170→- **Development Mode**: Separate WASM dev builds for faster iteration
   171→- **Parallel Builds**: Independent WASM crates build in parallel
   172→
   173→## External Dependencies
   174→
   175→### Required Services
   176→- **MoQ Relay**: For voice chat functionality
   177→  - Local: `just moq-relay` (auto-clones kixelated/moq)
   178→  - Public: https://moq.justinmoon.com/anon (fallback)
   179→- **Nostr Relays**: For identity and discovery
   180→  - Configured via Applesauce SDK
   181→
   182→### Development Tools
   183→- **wasm-pack**: WASM compilation and packaging
   184→- **cargo**: Rust build system
   185→- **bun**: JavaScript/TypeScript package manager and runtime
   186→- **just**: Task runner
   187→- **vite**: Frontend build tool and dev server
   188→
   189→### Optional Tools
   190→- **mkcert**: For generating local TLS certificates
   191→- **worldtool**: CLI for Nostr and MoQ relay management
   192→
   193→## Build Commands
   194→
   195→### Development
   196→- `just dev` - Build WASM (dev mode) + start dev server
   197→- `just build-wasm-dev` - Build all WASM modules in dev mode
   198→- `cd packages/app && bun run dev` - Frontend only (WASM must exist)
   199→
   200→### Production
   201→- `just build` - Build everything for production (WASM + frontend)
   202→- `just build-wasm` - Build all WASM modules in release mode
   203→
   204→### Testing & Validation
   205→- `just test` - Run all tests (Rust + TypeScript)
   206→- `just check` - Pre-deployment validation (check, clippy, fmt, build)
   207→- `cargo test --workspace` - Rust tests only
   208→
   209→### Utilities
   210→- `just clean` - Clean build artifacts
   211→- `just install` - Install dependencies
   212→- `just preview` - Preview production build
   213→- `just start-live` - Initialize Nostr live event
   214→- `just moq-relay` - Run local MoQ relay server
   215→
   216→## Project Structure
   217→
   218→### Workspace Organization
   219→```
   220→crossworld/
   221→├── crates/           # Rust crates (compiled to WASM)
   222→│   ├── world/       # Main world simulation + WASM bindings
   223→│   ├── cube/        # Voxel octree engine
   224→│   ├── physics/     # Rapier3D integration
   225→│   ├── renderer/    # CPU raytracer
   226→│   ├── assets/      # Asset management
   227→│   └── worldtool/   # CLI tool (not compiled to WASM)
   228→├── packages/
   229→│   ├── app/         # Main React application
   230→│   ├── common/      # Shared UI components
   231→│   ├── editor/      # Voxel model editor
   232→│   ├── wasm-world/  # Generated from crates/world
   23

discovery → requirements → context → spec_writing → planning → validation

entries.detail:
1→# OpenSpec Instructions
     2→
     3→Instructions for AI coding assistants using OpenSpec for spec-driven development.
     4→
     5→Additionally read crossworld-specs.md for high level and important and override specs.
     6→
     7→## TL;DR Quick Checklist
     8→
     9→- Search existing work: `openspec spec list --long`, `openspec list` (use `rg` only for full-text search)
    10→- Decide scope: new capability vs modify existing capability
    11→- Pick a unique `change-id`: kebab-case, verb-led (`add-`, `update-`, `remove-`, `refactor-`)
    12→- Scaffold: `proposal.md`, `tasks.md`, `design.md` (only if needed), and delta specs per affected capability
    13→- Write deltas: use `## ADDED|MODIFIED|REMOVED|RENAMED Requirements`; include at least one `#### Scenario:` per requirement
    14→- Validate: `openspec validate [change-id] --strict` and fix issues
    15→- Request approval: Do not start implementation until proposal is approved
    16→
    17→## Three-Stage Workflow
    18→
    19→### Stage 1: Creating Changes
    20→Create proposal when you need to:
    21→- Add features or functionality
    22→- Make breaking changes (API, schema)
    23→- Change architecture or patterns  
    24→- Optimize performance (changes behavior)
    25→- Update security patterns
    26→
    27→Triggers (examples):
    28→- "Help me create a change proposal"
    29→- "Help me plan a change"
    30→- "Help me create a proposal"
    31→- "I want to create a spec proposal"
    32→- "I want to create a spec"
    33→
    34→Loose matching guidance:
    35→- Contains one of: `proposal`, `change`, `spec`
    36→- With one of: `create`, `plan`, `make`, `start`, `help`
    37→
    38→Skip proposal for:
    39→- Bug fixes (restore intended behavior)
    40→- Typos, formatting, comments
    41→- Dependency updates (non-breaking)
    42→- Configuration changes
    43→- Tests for existing behavior
    44→
    45→**Workflow**
    46→1. Review `openspec/project.md`, `openspec list`, and `openspec list --specs` to understand current context.
    47→2. Choose a unique verb-led `change-id` and scaffold `proposal.md`, `tasks.md`, optional `design.md`, and spec deltas under `openspec/changes/<id>/`.
    48→3. Draft spec deltas using `## ADDED|MODIFIED|REMOVED Requirements` with at least one `#### Scenario:` per requirement.
    49→4. Run `openspec validate <id> --strict` and resolve any issues before sharing the proposal.
    50→
    51→### Stage 2: Implementing Changes
    52→Track these steps as TODOs and complete them one by one.
    53→1. **Read proposal.md** - Understand what's being built
    54→2. **Read design.md** (if exists) - Review technical decisions
    55→3. **Read tasks.md** - Get implementation checklist
    56→4. **Implement tasks sequentially** - Complete in order
    57→5. **Confirm completion** - Ensure every item in `tasks.md` is finished before updating statuses
    58→6. **Update checklist** - After all work is done, set every task to `- [x]` so the list reflects reality
    59→7. **Approval gate** - Do not start implementation until the proposal is reviewed and approved
    60→
    61→### Stage 3: Archiving Changes
    62→After deployment, create separate PR to:
    63→- Move `changes/[name]/` → `changes/archive/YYYY-MM-DD-[name]/`
    64→- Update `specs/` if capabilities changed
    65→- Use `openspec archive <change-id> --skip-specs --yes` for tooling-only changes (always pass the change ID explicitly)
    66→- Run `openspec validate --strict` to confirm the archived change passes checks
    67→
    68→## Before Any Task
    69→
    70→**Context Checklist:**
    71→- [ ] Read relevant specs in `specs/[capability]/spec.md`
    72→- [ ] Check pending changes in `changes/` for conflicts
    73→- [ ] Read `openspec/project.md` for conventions
    74→- [ ] Run `openspec list` to see active changes
    75→- [ ] Run `openspec list --specs` to see existing capabilities
    76→
    77→**Before Creating Specs:**
    78→- Always check if capability already exists
    79→- Prefer modifying existing specs over creating duplicates
    80→- Use `openspec show [spec]` to review current state
    81→- If request is ambiguous, ask 1–2 clarifying questions before scaffolding
    82→
    83→### Search Guidance
    84→- Enumerate specs: `openspec spec list --long` (or `--json` for scripts)
    85→- Enumerate changes: `openspec list` (or `openspec change list --json` - deprecated but available)
    86→- Show details:
    87→  - Spec: `openspec show <spec-id> --type spec` (use `--json` for filters)
    88→  - Change: `openspec show <change-id> --json --deltas-only`
    89→- Full-text search (use ripgrep): `rg -n "Requirement:|Scenario:" openspec/specs`
    90→
    91→## Quick Start
    92→
    93→### CLI Commands
    94→
    95→```bash
    96→# Essential commands
    97→openspec list                  # List active changes
    98→openspec list --specs          # List specifications
    99→openspec show [item]           # Display change or spec
   100→openspec validate [item]       # Validate changes or specs
   101→openspec archive <change-id> [--yes|-y]   # Archive after deployment (add --yes for non-interactive runs)
   102→
   103→# Project management
   104→openspec init [path]           # Initialize OpenSpec
   105→openspec update [path]         # Update instruction files
   106→
   107→# Interactive mode
   108→openspec show                  # Prompts for selection
   109→openspec validate              # Bulk validation mode
   110→
   111→# Debugging
   112→openspec show [change] --json --deltas-only
   113→openspec validate [change] --strict
   114→```
   115→
   116→### Command Flags
   117→
   118→- `--json` - Machine-readable output
   119→- `--type change|spec` - Disambiguate items
   120→- `--strict` - Comprehensive validation
   121→- `--no-interactive` - Disable prompts
   122→- `--skip-specs` - Archive without spec updates
   123→- `--yes`/`-y` - Skip confirmation prompts (non-interactive archive)
   124→
   125→## Directory Structure
   126→
   127→```
   128→openspec/
   129→├── project.md              # Project conventions
   130→├── specs/                  # Current truth - what IS built
   131→│   └── [capability]/       # Single focused capability
   132→│       ├── spec.md         # Requirements and scenarios
   133→│       └── design.md       # Technical patterns
   134→├── changes/                # Proposals - what SHOULD change
   135→│   ├── [change-name]/

   141→│   │           └── spec.md # ADDED/MODIFIED/REMOVED
   142→│   └── archive/            # Completed changes
   143→```
   144→
   145→## Creating Change Proposals
   146→
   147→### Decision Tree
   148→
   149→```
   150→New request?
   151→├─ Bug fix restoring spec behavior? → Fix directly
   152→├─ Typo/format/comment? → Fix directly  
   153→├─ New feature/capability? → Create proposal
   154→├─ Breaking change? → Create proposal
   155→├─ Architecture change? → Create proposal
   156→└─ Unclear? → Create proposal (safer)
   157→```
   158→
   159→### Proposal Structure
   160→
   161→1. **Create directory:** `changes/[change-id]/` (kebab-case, verb-led, unique)
   162→
   163→2. **Write proposal.md:**
   164→```markdown
   165→# Change: [Brief description of change]
   166→
   167→## Why
   168→[1-2 sentences on problem/opportunity]
   169→
   170→## What Changes
   171→- [Bullet list of changes]
   172→- [Mark breaking changes with **BREAKING**]
   173→
   174→## Impact
   175→- Affected specs: [list capabilities]
   176→- Affected code: [key files/systems]
   177→```
   178→
   179→3. **Create spec deltas:** `specs/[capability]/spec.md`
   180→```markdown
   181→## ADDED Requirements
   182→### Requirement: New Feature
   183→The system SHALL provide...
   184→
   185→#### Scenario: Success case
   186→- **WHEN** user performs action
   187→- **THEN** expected result
   188→
   189→## MODIFIED Requirements
   190→### Requirement: Existing Feature
   191→[Complete modified requirement]
   192→
   193→## REMOVED Requirements

   195→**Reason**: [Why removing]
   196→**Migration**: [How to handle]
   197→```
   198→If multiple capabilities are affected, create multiple delta files under `changes/[change-id]/specs/<capability>/spec.md`—one per capability.
   199→
   200→4. **Create tasks.md:**
   201→```markdown
   202→## 1. Implementation
   203→- [ ] 1.1 Create database schema
   204→- [ ] 1.2 Implement API endpoint
   205→- [ ] 1.3 Add frontend component
   206→- [ ] 1.4 Write tests
   207→```
   208→
   209→5. **Create design.md when needed:**
   210→Create `design.md` if any of the following apply; otherwise omit it:
   211→- Cross-cutting change (multiple services/modules) or a new architectural pattern
   212→- New external dependency or significant data model changes
   213→- Security, performance, or migration complexity
   214→- Ambiguity that benefits from technical decisions before coding
   215→
   216→Minimal `design.md` skeleton:

   221→## Goals / Non-Goals

1→# Improve Renderer Quality and Architecture
     2→
     3→## Summary
     4→
     5→Fix rendering quality issues in the renderer crate's mesh renderer, improve code architecture by renaming components for clarity, add mesh caching options, and update documentation.
     6→
     7→## Motivation
     8→
     9→The renderer crate currently has several quality and usability issues:
    10→
    11→1. **Mesh renderer camera calculation is incorrect** - The mesh renderer doesn't properly synchronize camera configuration with other renderers (CPU, GL, GPU), resulting in different viewpoints and making comparison difficult.
    12→
    13→2. **Mesh face rendering has visual artifacts** - Front/back face culling may be inverted or incorrectly configured, causing rendering issues.
    14→
    15→3. **Inefficient mesh regeneration** - The mesh is potentially regenerated every frame even when the voxel data hasn't changed, wasting GPU upload bandwidth and CPU cycles.
    16→
    17→4. **Unclear naming** - "DualRenderer" is now a misnomer as the system has expanded to five renderers (CPU, GL, BCF CPU, GPU, Mesh). The name should reflect its role as a comprehensive cube rendering comparison tool.
    18→
    19→5. **Outdated documentation** - README and documentation still refer to "dual" renderer and don't document the mesh renderer or recent additions.
    20→
    21→## Goals
    22→
    23→1. Fix mesh renderer camera synchronization to match other renderers
    24→2. Fix mesh renderer face culling/rendering issues
    25→3. Add option to cache/regenerate mesh on demand instead of every frame
    26→4. Rename `DualRendererApp` to `CubeRendererApp` throughout the codebase
    27→5. Update README.md and documentation to reflect current capabilities
    28→
    29→## Non-Goals
    30→
    31→- Rewriting the mesh generation algorithm
    32→- Adding new rendering backends
    33→- Changing the GUI framework or layout
    34→- Performance optimization beyond mesh caching
    35→
    36→## Impact
    37→
    38→### Users
    39→- **Positive**: Mesh renderer will produce correct output for visual comparison
    40→- **Positive**: Mesh caching option will improve frame rates when editing voxel data
    41→- **Positive**: Clearer naming makes code easier to understand
    42→- **Neutral**: Documentation updates reflect current state
    43→
    44→### Codebase
    45→- **Low Impact**: Mostly local changes to renderer crate
    46→- **Renaming**: `DualRendererApp` → `CubeRendererApp` (search and replace)
    47→- **New Feature**: Mesh cache toggle in UI settings
    48→
    49→### Dependencies
    50→- **None**: No external dependency changes
    51→
    52→## Open Questions
    53→
    54→1. **Mesh cache invalidation**: Should mesh cache be invalidated automatically when model changes, or require manual regeneration button?
    55→   - **Recommendation**: Automatic invalidation on model change + manual regeneration button for user control
    56→
    57→2. **Default mesh caching state**: Should mesh caching be enabled by default?
    58→   - **Recommendation**: Enabled by default for better performance, with clear UI indication
    59→
    60→3. **Camera sync validation**: Should we add validation tests to ensure all renderers use the same camera?
    61→   - **Recommendation**: Yes, add integration test comparing camera matrices across renderers
    62→
    63→## Alternatives Considered
    64→
    65→### Alternative 1: Keep "DualRenderer" name
    66→**Rejected**: Misleading as system now has 5 renderers. Would cause confusion for future contributors.
    67→
    68→### Alternative 2: Remove mesh renderer instead of fixing it
    69→**Rejected**: Mesh renderer provides unique value for validating mesh generation pipeline and comparing rasterization vs raytracing.
    70→
    71→### Alternative 3: Always regenerate mesh
    72→**Rejected**: Wasteful for static scenes. Caching with invalidation is standard practice.

# Improve Renderer Quality and Architecture

## Summary

Fix rendering quality issues in the renderer crate's mesh renderer, improve code architecture by renaming components for clarity, add mesh caching options, and update documentation.

## Motivation

The renderer crate currently has several quality and usability issues:

1. **Mesh renderer camera calculation is incorrect** - The mesh renderer doesn't properly synchronize camera configuration with other renderers (CPU, GL, GPU), resulting in different viewpoints and making comparison difficult.

2. **Mesh face rendering has visual artifacts** - Front/back face culling may be inverted or incorrectly configured, causing rendering issues.

3. **Inefficient mesh regeneration** - The mesh is potentially regenerated every frame even when the voxel data hasn't changed, wasting GPU upload bandwidth and CPU cycles.

4. **Unclear naming** - "DualRenderer" is now a misnomer as the system has expanded to five renderers (CPU, GL, BCF CPU, GPU, Mesh). The name should reflect its role as a comprehensive cube rendering comparison tool.

5. **Outdated documentation** - README and documentation still refer to "dual" renderer and don't document the mesh renderer or recent additions.

## Goals

1. Fix mesh renderer camera synchronization to match other renderers
2. Fix mesh renderer face culling/rendering issues
3. Add option to cache/regenerate mesh on demand instead of every frame
4. Rename `DualRendererApp` to `CubeRendererApp` throughout the codebase
5. Update README.md and documentation to reflect current capabilities

## Non-Goals

=== /home/k0/work/crossworld/main-cw/openspec/changes/create-bevy-voxel-editor/proposal.md ===
# Change: Create Bevy-based Voxel Editor

## Why

The project currently has:
1. A web-based TypeScript editor (`packages/editor`) focused on integration with the Chakra UI React app
2. A native OpenGL renderer (`crates/renderer`) with low-level glow/glutin/egui that serves as a test harness

We need a dedicated native voxel editor application with:
- Better ergonomics and UI/UX for content creators building voxel models
- Faster iteration cycles (no web browser overhead)
- Native performance for complex voxel scenes
- Modern Rust game engine architecture (Bevy ECS)
- Reuse of existing `cube` and `world` crate infrastructure

This fills the gap between the basic web editor and the low-level OpenGL test renderer, providing a production-quality tool for artists and level designers.

## What Changes

- **NEW**: Create `crates/editor` - Standalone Bevy application for voxel editing
- Reuse existing `cube` crate for octree operations, mesh generation, CSM parsing
- Reuse existing `world` crate for multi-depth world generation and editing
- Implement Bevy systems for:
  - 3D viewport with camera controls (orbit, pan, zoom)
  - Voxel placement/removal via raycasting
  - CSM import/export UI
  - Material palette selection
  - Scene hierarchy and layer management
  - Undo/redo system
- Desktop-native UI using `bevy_egui` for immediate-mode panels
=== /home/k0/work/crossworld/main-cw/openspec/changes/refactor-renderer-interface/proposal.md ===
# Change: Refactor Renderer Interface for Cross-Crate Usability

## Why

The renderer crate currently has renderer implementations scattered across multiple top-level modules (cpu_tracer.rs, gl_tracer.rs, bcf_cpu_tracer.rs, gpu_tracer.rs, mesh_renderer.rs). While there is a `Renderer` trait, it's not consistently implemented by all renderers (e.g., `MeshRenderer` doesn't implement it), and the interface is limited to basic `render()` methods without support for common GL operations like initialization and cleanup.

Other crates like `proto-gl` need to use these renderers but currently must work with inconsistent APIs. Some renderers require GL context initialization (`init_gl`), some have image buffers, some render directly to framebuffers. This makes it difficult to write generic rendering code.

## What Changes

- **Create unified Renderer interface** that supports:
  - Common rendering operations (`render`, `render_with_camera`)
  - GL-specific lifecycle (`init_gl`, `destroy_gl`, `render_to_framebuffer`)
  - Capability queries (`supports_gl`, `supports_image_output`, `name`)
  - File output for all renderers (`save_to_file`) - software renderers save from image buffer, GL renderers read back framebuffer

- **Reorganize module structure**:
  - Move all renderer implementations to `src/renderers/` module
  - Split `renderer.rs` into focused files: `renderer.rs` (trait), `camera.rs`, `lighting.rs`
  - Update exports in `lib.rs` for backward compatibility

- **Make MeshRenderer implement Renderer trait** with proper interface

- **Add renderer lifecycle management** for GL-based renderers

- **Update proto-gl** to use the unified interface

## Architecture Clarification

- **cube crate**: Octree data structure (Cube<T>, BCF serialization, mesh generation)
=== /home/k0/work/crossworld/main-cw/openspec/changes/implement-gpu-raytracer/proposal.md ===
# Change: Implement GPU Raytracer with Cube Raytracing

## Why

The renderer currently only supports CPU-based raytracing through `cpu_tracer.rs`, which integrates the cube crate's raycast implementation. To enable high-performance voxel rendering in the browser, we need a GPU-based raytracer that can leverage WebGL/WebGPU compute capabilities.

**Current situation:**
- `cpu_tracer.rs` - Uses `cube::Cube::raycast()` for CPU-based raytracing
- `gpu_tracer.rs` - Contains only stub implementation
- No GPU shader implementation for octree traversal

**Impact:** Without GPU raytracing, rendering performance is limited by JavaScript/WASM CPU execution speed, making real-time voxel rendering at higher resolutions impractical.

**Scope:** Implement GPU raytracer with shader-based octree traversal, matching the functionality of the CPU raytracer but optimized for parallel execution on the GPU.

## What Changes

### Phase 1: GPU Shader Implementation
- **`crates/renderer/src/shaders/`** - Create raycast shader
  - Implement octree traversal in GLSL/WGSL
  - Port cube raycast DDA algorithm to shader code
  - Add voxel value lookup and empty space detection
  - Calculate surface normals from entry face
  - Support configurable max depth for traversal
  - Handle coordinate space transformations (world space ↔ normalized [0,1]³)

### Phase 2: GPU Tracer Integration
- **`crates/renderer/src/gpu_tracer.rs`** - Implement GPU raytracer
  - Replace stub implementation with actual GPU integration
  - Setup shader program and uniforms
=== /home/k0/work/crossworld/main-cw/openspec/changes/add-terrain-composite-collider/proposal.md ===
# Change: Add Terrain Composite Collider with TypedSimdCompositeShape

## Why

The current world collision implementation uses either:
1. **Monolithic compound collider**: Pre-generates all terrain faces as a single compound shape (slow initialization, large memory)
2. **Direct octree queries**: Bypasses Rapier entirely for terrain collision (`WorldCollider::resolve_collision`)

Neither approach leverages Rapier's efficient `TypedSimdCompositeShape` trait, which allows lazy on-demand triangle generation during narrowphase collision detection. This trait enables the terrain to appear as a single collider while generating geometry only for regions actively queried.

The design document at `doc/architecture/cubeworld-collision.md` outlines the integration pattern using the cube crate's existing `visit_faces_in_region()` and `RegionBounds` for efficient spatial queries.

## What Changes

### New Terrain Collider System

1. **RegionId and TerrainPartId**: Compact encodings for identifying collision regions and individual triangles within the octree coordinate system.

2. **RegionCollisionData Cache**: Per-region cache that stores faces queried via `visit_faces_in_region()`, avoiding repeated octree traversal.

3. **Triangle Generation**: Convert cube crate `FaceInfo` to Rapier `Triangle` shapes on demand (2 triangles per face).

4. **Two-Level QBVH**: Coarse region-level QBVH + fine triangle-level QBVH for active regions near dynamic objects.

5. **TypedSimdCompositeShape Implementation**: Integrate with Rapier's narrowphase by implementing the composite shape trait.

6. **Active Region Tracking**: Only build triangle QBVH for regions near dynamic bodies.

### Integration Points

=== /home/k0/work/crossworld/main-cw/openspec/changes/create-bevy-physics-prototype/proposal.md ===
# Change: Create Bevy Physics Prototype

## Why

The project needs a standalone native physics prototype to validate and demonstrate advanced voxel physics capabilities:

1. **Physics Validation**: Test Rapier3D physics integration with complex voxel colliders before integrating into the web application
2. **Performance Benchmarking**: Measure performance of voxel collider generation and physics simulation with multiple objects
3. **Collider Optimization**: Develop and test optimized face-based collision detection that only processes overlapping volume regions
4. **Character Controller Testing**: Validate character physics (player cube) alongside dynamic voxel objects
5. **Configuration System**: Design TOML-based world configuration that can later be ported to the web app

This prototype builds on the existing `crates/editor` Bevy foundation but focuses on physics simulation rather than editing.

## What Changes

- **NEW**: Create `crates/proto` - Standalone Bevy application for physics prototyping
- **ENHANCED**: Extend `crates/physics` with optimized voxel collider generation:
  - Face-based collision traversal algorithm
  - Spatial filtering to only process overlapping volume regions between colliders
  - Native Bevy integration (non-WASM features)

- Reuse existing `world` crate for world generation
- Implement Bevy systems for:

  - Spawning dynamic voxel cubes at random positions in the air
  - Physics simulation with falling objects

   101→```
   102→
   103→## Files to Modify
   104→
   105→| File | Service | What to Change |
   106→|------|---------|---------------|
   107→| `.auto-claude/specs/003-*/` | auto-claude | Create new task directories for each active openspec change |
   108→| `openspec/changes/*/proposal.md` | openspec | Read for requirements extraction |
   109→| `openspec/changes/*/tasks.md` | openspec | Read for subtask extraction |
   110→
   111→## Files to Reference
   112→
   113→These files show patterns to follow:
   114→
   115→| File | Pattern to Copy |
   116→|------|----------------|
   117→| `.auto-claude/specs/001-physics-optimization/implementation_plan.json` | Task JSON structure |
   118→| `.auto-claude/specs/001-physics-optimization/requirements.json` | Requirements format |
   119→| `openspec/AGENTS.md` | Understanding openspec workflow |
   120→| `openspec/project.md` | Project context and conventions |
   121→
   122→## Patterns to Follow
   123→
   124→### Task ID Naming
   125→
   126→From existing `.auto-claude/specs/`:
   127→
   128→- Format: `NNN-kebab-case-name`
   129→- Example: `001-physics-optimization`, `002-openspec-tasks`
   130→- Next available: `003-*` through `013-*` for 11 active changes
   131→
   132→### Requirements JSON Pattern
   133→
   134→```json
   135→{
   136→  "task_description": "Brief description of what needs to be done",
   137→  "workflow_type": "feature|refactor|investigation"
   138→}
   139→```
   140→
   141→### Implementation Plan Pattern
   142→
   143→Extract from openspec tasks.md checkbox items:
   144→- `- [ ]` -> `"status": "pending"`
   145→- `- [x]` -> `"status": "completed"`
   146→
   147→Group by phase headings (## Phase N) in tasks.md.
   148→
   149→## Requirements
   150→
   151→### Functional Requirements
   152→
   153→1. **Extract Active Tasks**
   154→   - Description: Parse all 11 active openspec changes and extract incomplete tasks
   155→   - Acceptance: Each openspec change maps to one `.auto-claude/specs/` directory
   156→
   157→2. **Preserve Task Status**
   158→   - Description: Maintain completion status of partially-done changes
   159→   - Acceptance: Tasks marked `[x]` in openspec appear as `"completed"` in JSON
   160→
   161→3. **Capture Requirements Context**
   162→   - Description: Extract motivation, goals, and impact from proposal.md
   163→   - Acceptance: Each task has meaningful `task_description` from proposal
   164→
   165→4. **Create Valid JSON**
   166→   - Description: Generated files must be valid JSON matching existing patterns
   167→   - Acceptance: All JSON files parse without errors
   168→
   169→5. **Deprecate Old Files**
   170→   - Description: After successful migration, mark or remove openspec changes
   171→   - Acceptance: Clear indication that migration is complete
   172→
   173→### Edge Cases
   174→
   175→1. **Partially Complete Changes** - Changes like `improve-renderer-quality` and `optimize-world-collision` have mixed [x]/[ ] status. Extract only pending tasks but note completed work in context.
   176→
   177→2. **Empty Task Phases** - Some phases may be entirely complete. Skip them or include as completed context.
   178→
   179→3. **Design Documents** - Include `design.md` content in spec.md if present, not as separate file.
   180→
   181→4. **Delta Specs** - Openspec delta specs (`specs/*/spec.md` under changes) are capability-specific. Include as context in new spec.md.
   182→
   183→## Implementation Notes
   184→
   185→### DO
   186→- Follow the task ID numbering pattern (003, 004, ... 013)
   187→- Parse markdown checkboxes accurately (`- [ ]` vs `- [x]`)
   188→- Preserve the hierarchical structure of phases/subtasks
   189→- Create one auto-claude task per openspec change
   190→- Include sufficient context from proposal.md for future implementation
   191→
   192→### DON'T
   193→- Create tasks for archived openspec changes
   194→- Remove openspec files before verifying migration success
   195→- Modify the openspec CLI commands (`.claude/commands/openspec/`)
   196→- Attempt to implement any of the planned changes during migration
   197→
   198→## Migration Mapping
   199→
   200→| OpenSpec Change | New Task ID | Priority |
   201→|-----------------|-------------|----------|
   202→| `optimize-world-collision` | `003-world-collision-optimization` | High (in progress) |
   203→| `improve-renderer-quality` | `004-renderer-quality` | High (in progress) |
   204→| `implement-gpu-raytracer` | `005-gpu-raytracer` | Medium |
   205→| `refactor-renderer-interface` | `006-renderer-interface` | Medium |
   206→| `create-proto-gl-physics-viewer` | `007-proto-gl-viewer` | Low (superseded?) |
   207→| `create-bevy-physics-prototype` | `008-bevy-physics` | Low |
   208→| `create-bevy-voxel-editor` | `009-bevy-editor` | Low |
   209→| `add-fabric-model-generation` | `010-fabric-model` | Medium |
   210→| `add-function-cube-type` | `011-function-cube` | Medium |
   211→| `add-terrain-composite-collider` | `012-terrain-collider` | Medium |
   212→
   213→## Development Environment
   214→
   215→### Relevant Directories
   216→
   217→```bash
   218→# Source: openspec active changes
   219→ls openspec/changes/
   220→
   221→# Target: auto-claude specs
   222→ls .auto-claude/specs/
   223→
   224→# Reference: existing task
   225→cat .auto-claude/specs/001-physics-optimization/implementation_plan.json
   226→```
   227→
   228→### Validation Commands
   229→
   230→```bash
   231→# Verify JSON validity
   232→python3 -c "import json; json.load(open('.auto-claude/specs/003-*/implementation_plan.json'))"
   233→
   234→# Count migrated tasks
   235→ls -d .auto-claude/specs/*/ | wc -l
   236→
   237→# Verify no incomplete openspec changes remain
   238→find openspec/changes -maxdepth 1 -type d ! -name archive | wc -l
   239→```
